definition:
Let $I\subset\mathbb{R}$ be a real interval, $f$ a real-valued function
on $I$, and let $M$ be an $n\times n$ real symmetric (and thus
Hermitian) matrix whose eigenvalues are contained in $I$.

By the spectral theorem, we can diagonalize $M$ by an orthogonal matrix
$O$, so we can write $M=ODO^{-1}$ where $D$ is the diagonal matrix
consisting of the eigenvalues
$\{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\ldots,\lambda_n\}$. We then define

$$\begin{aligned}
f(A)=Of(D)O^{-1},\end{aligned}$$

where $f(D)$ denotes the diagonal matrix whose diagonal entries are
given by $f(\lambda_i)$.

It is easy to verify that $f(A)$ is well-defined, i.e. a permutation of
the eigenvalues corresponds to the same definition of $f(A)$.
